prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together, and he pays all the bills because she only works part-time. The issue started when he asked her to pay for takeout that cost under $40 because he left his wallet. She had a "ugly" attitude about it, and now he's considering making her start paying some bills because of this incident.

First, I need to consider their financial arrangement. If she's working part-time, maybe she doesn't earn much, but the author is paying everything. The author might feel that since she isn't contributing, even a small amount, it's unfair. But is it fair for him to hold a single incident up as a reason to change the entire financial arrangement?

The key points here are communication and expectations. Did they ever discuss how they split expenses? If the author never talked about it before and just assumed he'd pay everything, maybe he's the one who set that precedent. The incident with the takeout might have been a trigger because he felt she wasn't pulling her weight, but reacting to a $40 expense by making her take over more bills seems a bit harsh, especially if her income is low. Also, the way he's reacting—focusing on her attitude during a minor incident—could indicate that his response is more about his feelings of being taken for granted than the actual amount in question.

On the other hand, the girlfriend's reaction might have been defensive if she's used to not contributing and suddenly being asked to pay even a small amount made her uncomfortable. However, the author's decision to use this as a catalyst for changing the financial arrangement without prior discussion might be unfair. It's possible that the author is projecting his frustration onto her, and by making her pay more because of this one incident, he's not considering her financial limitations.

So, the question is whether holding a single, minor incident to demand significant changes in financial responsibility is justified. If they hadn't discussed contributions before, the author might be the one in the wrong for not addressing the issue openly and instead using a small event as a reason to shift the dynamic. It's possible that a more constructive approach would be to talk about shared expenses rather than making a unilateral decision based on a single occurrence.
